==English==
{{wikipedia|Mars (mythology)|mul=Mars (planet)}}
[[File:Mars symbol.svg|thumb|Mars astronomical symbol]]
[[File:Mars_23_aug_2003_hubble.jpg|right|thumb|220px|Mars (planet)]]

===Pronunciation===
* {{a|RP}} {{IPA|en|/ˈmɑːz/}}
* {{a|GA}} {{IPA|en|/ˈmɑɹz/}}
* {{rhymes|en|ɑː(ɹ)z}}
* {{audio|en|en-us-mars.ogg|Audio (US)}}

===Etymology 1===
From {{inh|en|enm|Mars}}, from {{der|en|la|Mars||god of war}}, from older Latin (older than 75 {{BC}}) {{m|la|Māvors}}. {{m|osc|𐌌𐌀𐌌𐌄𐌓𐌔}} was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]].

====Proper noun====
{{en-proper noun}}

# {{senseid|en|Q111}} {{lb|en|astronomy}} The fourth planet in the [[solar system]]. Symbol: '''[[♂]]'''
#: {{ux|en|'''Mars''' has two moons, Deimos and Phobos.}}
# {{senseid|en|Q112}} {{lb|en|Roman god}} The [[Roman]] [[god]] of [[war]].
#: {{syn|en|Ares}}
#: {{ux|en|'''Mars''' was the lover of Venus, and together they had a daughter called Harmonia.}}
# {{lb|en|poetic}} [[war|War]]; a [[personification]] of war.
#: {{ux|en|In the first half of the twentieth century, '''Mars''' devastated Europe.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|passage='''Mars''' rode upon the storm of horror and drank his fill of pain and blood. When the Serbian Army retreated before the foe, four times its own strength, it went backward facing the enemy and fighting every step of the way.|title=A Nation at Bay: What an American Woman Saw and Did in Suffering Serbia|page=57|author=Ruth Stanley Farnam|year=1918}}
#* {{quote-journal|en|passage=A relieved world then will eagerly turn to the task of reclaiming the destruction wrought by '''Mars''' ... A tremendous task, filled with infinite possibilities ... A profitable task, according to how well you are prepared to do your part in the rehabilitation ...|magazine=Engineering and Mining Journal|volume=145|page=54|year=1944|author=McGraw-Hill}}
#* {{quote-book|en|passage=The plague, inevitable companion of '''Mars''', ravaged the populace.|title=Jacques Callot: Prints & Related Drawings, Issue 21|author=Helen Diane Russell, Jeffrey Blanchard|year=1975|page=10}}

From {{m+|itc-ola|Māvors}}, from {{inh|la|itc-pro|*Māwortis}}. ''Mamers'' was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]].

===Pronunciation===
* {{la-IPA|Mārs}}

===Proper noun===
{{la-proper noun|Mārs<3>|g=m}}

# {{senseid|la|Q111}}{{topics|la|Planets of the Solar System}}{{l|en|Mars}} (planet)
# {{senseid|la|Q112}}{{topics|la|Roman deities}}[[#English|Mars]] (Roman god)

===Usage notes===
The name of the god could, through {{m|la|interpretatio romana}}, serve to replace the name of a war god in a foreign language. Thus [[w:Saxo Grammaticus|Saxo Grammaticus]], for example, uses the term to refer to the Norse god [[Odin]], alternating it with the borrowed form {{m|la|Ōthinus}}.

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|Mārs<3>}}

===Noun===
{{la-noun|Mārs<3.both>|g=m}}

# [[war]], [[battle]], [[conflict]]

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|Mārs<3.both>}}
